metadata.title: On the fouling formation of functionalized and non-functionalized carbon nanotube nano-fluids under pool boiling condition

sections.text:
Research Paper
On the fouling formation of functionalized and non-functionalized carbon nanotube nano-fluids under pool boiling condition M.M. Sarafraz a,*, F. Hormozi a, M. Silakhori b, S.M. Peyghambarzadeh c
a Faculty of Chemical, Petroleum and Gas Engineering, Semnan University, Semnan, Iran b Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Guilan, PO BOX 3756, Rasht, Iran c Department of Chemical Engineering, College of Chemical Engineering, Islamic Azad University, Mahshahr Branch, Mahshahr, Iran
H I G H L I G H T S
• Pool boiling heat transfer characteristics of CNT/water nano-fluid is studied. • Functionalized and non-functionalized CNT nano-fluids are investigated. • Fouling formation of both nano-fluid is experimentally studied. • Non-functionalized nano-fluid are found to enhance the CHF. • Functionalize nano-fluids are found to enhance the heat transfer coefficient.
A R T I C L E I N F O
Article history: Received 6 April 2015 Accepted 21 November 2015 Available online 27 November 2015
Keywords: Pool boiling Functionalized carbon nanotube Fouling formation Contact angle Critical heat flux
A B S T R A C T
Pool boiling heat transfer coefficient (HTC) of functionalized carbon nanotube (FCNT) and nonfunctionalized carbon nanotube (CNT) is experimentally quantified at high-heat flux conditions up to the critical heat flux (CHF) point. Nano-fluids are prepared using two-step method and are well dispersed within the deionized water, followed by functionalizing (by carboxyl group), sonication and adding the nonylphenolethoxylates nonionic surfactant as a dispersant. In terms of stability, results showed that FCNT could be stable up to three successive weeks, while seven days of stability was registered for nonFCNT. In addition, FCNT considerably enhance the heat transfer coefficient and CHF point. Since this nanofluid does not change the roughness of surface considerably and has great wettability in comparison with CNT nano-fluid. Results also demonstrated although fouling formation of functionalized carbon nanotube is insignificant in comparison with CNT, the lower contact angle between liquid droplet and the surface caused more liquid to be absorbed by the porous fouling layer. Therefore, more liquid are available on the surface, which leads the dry-out regions to be re-wetted. Consequently, significant enhancement in CHF point was registered for FCNT nano-fluids in comparison with CNT. In terms of fouling behavior, asymptotic behavior for fouling resistance is seen for CNT, while the rectilinear fouling behavior was seen for FCNT.
© 2015 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Efficient cooling in high heat flux surfaces such as semiconductors (e.g. processors), microelectronics or chemical reactors (e.g. pressurized water reactors) has been an interesting challenge for heat transfer experts. Boiling heat transfer provide superior heat transfer rate, which can be used in power cycles, refrigeration and cooling systems. This large quantity of heat can be achieved in case of utilizing the boiling mechanism, due to the phase change phenomenon, micro/macro bubble transports, and local agitation due
to the bubble interactions. Therefore, smaller surface is required for a system working in boiling condition. However, due to the complexities and limitations encountered in utilization of boiling, more studies are still required. Critical Heat Flux (CHF) in boiling heat transfer, as a definition, is a limited point in which, phase change process acts in a way that bubbles can cover and overwhelm the heating surface, which leads to the overheating problem. In this condition, heat transfer coefficient starts decreasing over the higher given heat fluxes, which can finally damage to the surface or explode the heater. Therefore, it is required to use efficient but high performance coolants in high heat flux systems. Nano-fluids (a traditional coolant such as water comprising the solid particles with size of 0–100 nm, which was called “Nano-fluids” by Choi [1]) are promising nominations for future of advanced thermal fluids due to their outstanding thermal conductivity. In fact, nano-fluids represent the * Corresponding author. Tel.: +989120976870; fax: +989214774016. E-mail address: mohamadmohsensarafraz@gmail.com (M.M. Sarafraz).
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.applthermaleng.2015.11.071 1359-4311/© 2015 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Applied Thermal Engineering
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/ locate /apthermeng
higher thermal conductivity rather than conventional coolants, sometimes 2-fold or 3- fold larger than that of the base fluid. Many efforts have been made to investigate the potential application of nanofluid in convective systems [2–10]. In general, positive results on enhancement of heat transfer have been obtained for the convective systems working with nano-fluid; although small penalties for pressure drop and pumping power have also been reported through the literature.
For nucleate boiling heat transfer, controversial literature has been found, which can be categorized in two different groups. The first group believes that boiling heat transfer coefficient can be enhanced by nano-fluids, since nano-fluids have better conductivity and convection coefficient [11–14]. The second group believes that due to the fouling of nanoparticles on the heating surface, number of nucleation sites can be reduced over the extend time [15–18]. However, both groups have a point in common, which implies in this fact that nano-fluids can enhance the boiling CHF. For example, Ahn and his co-workers [19] established experiments on forced convection and CHF characteristics of nano-fluids. The experimental results showed that the nano-fluid flow boiling CHF was distinctly enhanced under the forced convection flow conditions compared to that in pure water. Subsequent to the boiling experiments, the heater surfaces were examined with scanning electron microscope and by measuring contact angle. The surface characterization results implied on this fact that CHF enhancement is mostly caused by the nanoparticles deposition of the heater surface during vigorous boiling of nano-fluids and the subsequent wettability enhancements. Kim et al. [20] conducted an experimental study on flow boiling CHF of alumina nano-fluid and alumina coated tubes. The flow boiling CHF of alumina nano-fluid with a plain tube and de-ionized water with an alumina-coated tube were enhanced up to about 80% for all experimental conditions. There was no big difference in the CHF results between two methods. The obtained results indicate that the CHF enhancement of alumina nano-fluid is surely caused by deposition of nanoparticles on the test section tube inner surface. An experimental study was carried out by Yang and Liu [21] to investigate the pool boiling heat transfer characteristics of functionalized nano-fluid at atmospheric and subatmospheric pressures. Experimental results show that there exist great differences between pool boiling heat transfer characteristics of functionalized and traditional nano-fluid. The differences mainly result from the changes of surface characteristics of the heated surface during the boiling. Therefore, the pool boiling heat transfer of nano-fluids is governed by both the thermo-properties of nano-fluids and the surface characteristics of the heated surface. In another study, Song et al. [22] experimentally investigated on
boiling characteristic of SiC nano-fluid and evaluated the thermal performance of SiC nanoparticles in water pool boiling up to CHF. The volume concentrations of SiC nano-fluid were 0.0001%, 0.001%, and 0.01%. The CHF has been enhanced up to 105% for volume concentration 0.01%. CHF enhancement trend was interesting because it was not linearly dependent on nanoparticle concentration. The wettability change of SiC nanoparticle deposited surface was discussed as main reason of CHF enhancement variation. Boiling behaviors of ZnO nano-fluid on a horizontal and vertical plate in saturated pool boiling was experimentally studied by Mourgous et al. [23]. According to the previous works, it can be stated that CHF enhancement is the obvious consequence of using nano-fluid at boiling condition. The main reason for this fact can be referred to the fouling formation of nanoparticles on the surface, intensification of capillary wicking which causes changing in surface characteristics due to the deposition. Among the different nano-fluids that have been investigated by several authors, carbon nanotubes, CNTs are regarded as promising materials, which have superior thermal conductivity when they are dispersed uniformly within the base fluid. Table 1 presents the summary of some significant researches conducted on thermal conductivity measurement of carbon nanotube.
According to Table 1, a clear conclusion can be drawn as CNT nano-fluids have anomalous thermal properties, particularly thermal conductivity, while their boiling thermal behavior is not currently well known or is still understudied. In a recent work, Amiri et al. [32] has conducted experiments on pool boiling heat transfer of MWCNT/water nano-fluids. They investigated the influences of carbon nanotubes structures and different functional groups on the pool boiling heat transfer coefficient, HTC, using functionalizing method as a major stabilization process. Results showed that while the HTC of the non-covalent nano-fluid was lower than that of the deionized water, the covalent nano-fluids demonstrated a significant increase in HTC, while no information on deposition of MWCNT on the surface were reported. Kumar et al. [33] performed investigations regarding boiling heat transfer of multi-walled carbon nanotube suspension in pure water and water containing 9.0% by weight of sodium lauryl sulphate anionic surfactant (SDS) over the flat plate heater. The experimental data demonstrated that with adding the carbon nanotubes, boiling heat transfer coefficient could be increased in comparison with the base fluid. Moreover, surfactants had positive influences on the enhancement of heat transfer coefficient in boiling condition of CNTs. Results also revealed that with increasing heat flux, the enhancement was concealed due to vigorous bubble generation for both water/CNT and water/CNT/ surfactant nano-fluids. Foaming was also observed due to presence
Table 1 Researches on thermal conductivity of CNT nano-fluids.
Author CNT Base fluid Remarks
Xie et al. [24] MWCNT DI-water Thermal conductivity was measured using hot wire method for multi-walled CNT, Thermal conductivity enhancement = 7% at vol. % = 1. Chen et al. [25] MWCNT DI-water Thermal conductivity was measured using hot wire method for multi-walled CNT, Thermal conductivity enhancement = 12% at vol. % = 1. Assael et al. [26] MWCNT DI-water Thermal conductivity was measured using hot wire method for multi-walled CNT, Thermal conductivity enhancement = 38% at vol. % = 0.6, SDS was used as dispersant. Hwang et al. [27] MWCNT DI-water Thermal conductivity was measured using hot wire method for multi-walled CNT, Thermal conductivity enhancement = 21% and 13%, respectively for SDS and Triton X-100 at vol.% = 0.6%, SDS and Triton X-100 were used as dispersant Aravind [28] MWCNT Water/ethylene glycol Thermal conductivity was measured using Lambda instrument for multi-walled CNT, Thermal conductivity enhancement = 33–40% at vol. % = 0.03. Ding et al. [29] MWCNT DI-water Thermal conductivity was measured using KD2 Pro instrument for CNT (type was not specified), Thermal conductivity enhancement = 25% at wt. % = 0.5. Jha et al. [30] Ag/MWCNT DI-water Thermal conductivity was measured using KD2 Pro instrument for Ag/MWCNT composite nano-fluid, Thermal conductivity enhancement = 37.3% at vol. % = 0.03. Kim et al. [31] MWCNT DI-water Thermal conductivity was measured using hot wire method for multi-walled CNT, Thermal conductivity enhancement = 25% at wt. % = 0.01.
of surfactant over the liquid-free surface in water/CNT/surfactant nano-fluids during the investigation, and no fouling over the heating surface was observed or reported after experimentation. In other research, Kumar et al. [34] showed that enhancement in boiling heat transfer can be intensified using CNT coatings on the heating surface. Liu et al. [35] studied the pool boiling heat transfer of CNT nanofluids under subatmospheric pressure and concluded that pressure has great impacts on heat transfer coefficient. Jung et al. [36] established several experiments to quantify the nucleate pool boiling heat transfer coefficient and characteristics of aqueous CNT nanofluids up to critical heat flux on a square flat copper heater. Experimental results demonstrated that the pool boiling heat transfer coefficient of the CNT nano-fluids are lower than that of pure water in the entire nucleate boiling regime. In addition, experiments showed a thin layer of CNT deposit can be formed on the heater, which changes the surface characteristics and number of nucleation sites. In fact, this deposition decreases the number of active nucleation sites of the surface. According to the represented literature, CNT nano-fluids may have a conflicting behavior in boiling heat transfer, which should carefully be investigated.
In this work, an experimental study on pool boiling heat transfer characteristics of CNT nano-fluid is established to quantify the heat transfer coefficient up to critical heat flux point. Since, deposition of CNTs on the heater is the major challenge of the previous CNT-related studies, functionalizing process by carboxyl group is utilized to improve the repulsion forces in the bulk of nano-fluid. By doing this, stability of nano-fluid is considerably improved, which reduces the sedimentation and fouling of CNTs and rate of agglomeration. To obtain the exact role of deposition on pool boiling heat transfer coefficient and CHF, a parameter is defined, namely boiling fouling thermal resistance. Influence of different operating parameters on the heat transfer coefficient and fouling thermal resistance is experimentally investigated and deeply discussed.

sections.heading: 2.1. Experimental setup
sections.text:
Fig. 1 presents a schema of the experimental setup used for measuring the pool boiling heat transfer coefficient and CHF of CNT nanofluids. This test rig consists of four main sections:
• Discoid copper heater as the test section with boiling surface of 0.000078 m2 • Auxiliaries including pre-heater, condenser installed inside the test vessel • Temperature measurement instruments including thermocouples, indicators, data acquisition and a post processor (a pc computer) • Imaging system including a high-speed camera and a digital microscope with magnification of 500× (IP-U500x)
Nano-fluid is loaded through the inlet port of the test vessel. The vessel is a vertical Pyrex-made cylinder, which has enough thermal resistance against the high-temperature shock. At the bottom section of vessel, a perforated hole has been created, in which a discoid copper heater is mounted. A small layer of Teflon is used to prevent from any liquid leakage and heat loss between discoid heater and the hole. This discoid heater consists of a dual diameter cylinder with an axial concentric hole at the bottom, in which a 500-Watt bolt heater is plugged to supply the required heat. The required power for the heater was provided by an AC transformer connected to the urban power supply. Detailed geometrical properties of discoid heater are given in Fig. 2. The top surface of discoid heater is fixed horizontally inside the cap, so the surface can be used for pool boiling heat transfer and CHF experiments. The surface is circular with outer diameter of 11 mm. In order to measure the
temperature of surface, five k-type thermocouples with length of 50 mm and diameter of 1 mm (with precision of ±0.1K) are mounted in the axial holes (with different axial positions) on the upper section of heater. By installing the thermocouples, temperature gradient can accurately be measured, which precisely extrapolates the surface temperature of heater. To minimize the thermal resistance of each thermocouple, holes are filled with silicon paste. The circumference of the heater is heavily isolated by the cylindrical PTFE (polytetrafluoroethylene) solid to prevent from any heat losses. By heavily isolating the heater, axial heat transfer toward the surface is guaranteed, and no radial heat transfer can be seen in heater. To ensure about the radial heat transfer, two k-type thermocouples at (r = −0.5 cm, r = +0.5 cm) was mounted to measure the radially temperature distribution. Results showed that temperature at this two points are the same at any given heat fluxes. Thus, radial heat transfer can be ignored. For measuring the liquid bulk temperature, four RTDs (with precision of ±0.1K) are installed at four different locations of test vessel. The arithmetic average of RTD readings is considered as the bulk temperature of vessel. In addition, to ensure about saturated boiling, a thermocouple is mounted at the upper part of the vessel to measure the vapor temperature. A pressure transmitter is also installed to record the pressure inside the vessel. A safety pressure valve is connected to the pressure controller and pressure transmitter to control the pressure of vessel. An auxiliary heater is installed inside the vessel to supply the required heat for pre-heating of liquid up to saturation temperature. As soon as nano-fluid temperature reaches to the correspondence saturation
temperature and pressure, discoid heater is turned on for starting the pool boiling experiments.
Before running the experiments, initially, de-aerating process was performed in order to deplete the bulk of nano-fluid from any dissolved air. For this purpose, a vacuum pump was used at pressure of 50 kPa and for 30 minutes to de-aerate the nano-fluids. Simultaneously, temperature of nano-fluid gradually increased to 70 ?C to reduce the amount of oxygen (air) dissolved in bulk of fluid. Experiments were then pursued.

sections.heading: 2.2. Preparation of CNT/DIW nano-fluid
sections.text:
For preparing the nano-fluids, multi-walled carbon nanotubes was purchased from USNANO research with mean diameter of 10– 20 nm and tube length of 1.5–2 μm. Deionized water (DIW) was selected as the base fluid. For preparing the non-functionalized CNT, desire weight of CNT (at wt.% of 0.1–0.3) was initially dispersed in to the water/nonylphenolethoxylates using motorized magnetic stirrer with speed of 250 rpm for 30 minutes. Noticeably, surfactant can change the thermo-physical properties of nano-fluid; therefore, it was added to DIW at only 0.1% of general volume of nano-fluid. Then, nano-fluid was exposed to sonication process using ultrasonic 40 kHz/ 300Watt for 30 minutes to prevent from aggregation and possible clustering formation. In addition, for the best stability, pH of nanofluids was set using buffer solution of NaOH and HCl (0.1 millimolar). More information regarding the stabilizing process is given in Table 2. As the other stabilizing process, functionalizing process was
Table 2 Best results of stabilizing process for carbon nanotube nano-fluids.
Nano-fluid wt.% Stirring(min) Sonication (min)* pH setting Zeta potential** (mV) Stability
Non-functionalized (CNT)
0.1 180 30 8.2 −10 about 5 days 0.2 210 30 8.5 −15 about 5 days 0.3 250 30 8.9 −21 about 7 days
Functionalized (FCNT)
0.1 60 - - −50 about 21 days 0.2 60 - - −55 about 21 days 0.3 60 - - −60 about 21 days
* Sonication was performed using Dakota ultrasonic, **Zeta potential was measured using Malvern zeta analyzer.
implemented. In order to functionalize the CNTs, a reflux unit was set up and CNTs were refluxed with 3:1 HNO3 and H2SO4 acids. Subsequently, CNTs is refluxed again with carboxylic acid to be functionalized. The former two acids modify the surface of CNT and provide enough surface defects for attaching the carboxyl group to the sidewalls of CNTs. This COOH functional group is provided by the carboxylic acid. However, this method may have negative influence on electrical conductivity and corrosion resistance of CNTs, which can be ignored during the pool boiling heat transfer. The final product was filtered through PTFE filters and rinsed, dried and dispersed in deionized water at desire weight concentration (mass) without using any surfactants, sonication or pH setting.
Zeta potential of each nano-fluid was measured at the moststable condition and presented in Table 2. In addition, for designing the time settlement experiment, Response Surface Methodology (RSM) was employed, which optimized the number of experiments for stabilizing process.
Settlement-time experiments were also performed to examine the stability of nano-fluids. According to the results, FCNT represents longer stability without agglomeration in comparison with CNT nano-fluids. Fig. 3 (a) shows the results of settlement experiments for CNT nano-fluids. Fig. 3b represents the influence of ultrasonic on stability of CNT. As can clearly be seen, sonication can efficiently crack the agglomeration. Noticeably, images have been taken 7 days after stabilizing process and for wt.% = 0.3 of CNT. As can be seen, at pH = 8.9, CNTs have the stable behavior rather than other pH values. For FCNT, nano-fluids were stable for 21 days without any sonication, stirring and pH setting and at any mass concentration.
Quality tests were also performed to analyze the dispersion quality and purity of nanotubes. Fig. 4a shows the Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) image of CNT nano-fluid at wt. % = 0.1. As can be seen, nanotubes are similar in size and morphology. Fig. 4b demonstrates the X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) pattern of CNTs, which implies on this fact that NTs are pure, since there is no extra peak or pattern rather than carbon element and nanotube morphology. In addition, peaks are broad due to the nano-size effect. Fig. 4c shows the Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM) image of CNT nano-fluids.

sections.heading: 2.3. Data reduction, uncertainty and validation of experimental data
sections.text:
For estimating the pool boiling heat transfer coefficient, it is essential to extrapolate the surface temperature of discoid heater. The
criterion for thermal performance of a nano-fluid is the pool boiling heat transfer coefficient, which can be calculated using Eq. (1):
h q
T Tw b = − (1)
In Eq. (1), Tw is the surface temperature, and Tb is the bulk temperature of liquid, q is the applied heat flux to the liquid from the discoid heater, which can be calculated using Eq. (2):
q k dT dz
k T T zsurface axial = − = − −5 1 Δ (2)
Z is the axial direction (see Fig. 2). Noticeably, according to the Joule’s heating effect, heat flux can be directly estimated by Eq. (3) as follows:
q V I R = ⋅ ⋅π 2 (3)
In this equation, V is voltage (volt), I is electric current of central heater (Amps), and R is the radius of surface of discoid heater. Note that, circumference of discoid heater has been isolated with PTFE. Therefore, one dimensional conduction heat transfer is the reasonable dominant heat transfer mechanism. Thus, the following linear temperature distribution can be obtained based on Eq. (2):

sections.text: Since at z = 0, T = Tw, therefore, we have:

sections.heading: Tw = α (5)
sections.text:
Where, α is the intercept of the line fitted on the measured axial temperatures of discoid heater at a given heat flux. Therefore, alpha can be accurately estimated for each heat flux and is regarded as the surface temperature for each heat flux. A comparison between the heat fluxes estimated from Eq. (2) and that of calculated by Eq. (3) is made to show the quantity of heat loss along with the discoid heater. Fig. 5 shows the results of this comparison. Noticeably, thermocouples and multi-meter readings were carried out three times to ensure about reproducibility of data. It can be stated that at lower heat flux, higher uncertainty was seen (for some data more than 6%), while for high heat flux condition, lower uncertainty was registered.
As can be seen in Fig. 5a, uncertainty for heat fluxes is lower than 6%, meaning that heat can easily flow from cartridge heater toward the boiling surface, and rate of heat loss is reasonable and less than 6%. Figs. 5b shows the extrapolation of surface temperature using Eqs (1–5) for heat flux 400 kW/m2. In addition, a thermograph image (see Fig. 5c) has been taken from the surface at this heat flux and has been compared to extrapolated results. As can be seen, extrapolation is reliable and results are within the only 5% deviation. Since experiments are performed up to the critical heat flux point, the given heat flux to the boiling surface was increased in increments of 40 kW/m2 which was about +4.8 V for applied voltage in each step. For measuring the CHF point, heat flux continuously increased up to the point that with increasing the heat flux, the heat transfer coefficient was not changed and with a small increase in heat flux, lower heat transfer coefficient was measured. In this point, mushroom shaped bubbles form on the surface as well which can help to determine the exact point of the CHF.
For other heat fluxes, similar extrapolation method was performed. To check the uncertainty of experiments, Kline-McKlintock method [37] was used. A detailed uncertainty analysis performed on overall uncertainty of the pool boiling heat transfer coefficient, based on Eq. (3) and Eq. (1):
Δ Δ Δ Δq q V V I I A A = ⎡ ⎣⎢ ⎤ ⎦⎥ + ⎡ ⎣⎢ ⎤ ⎦⎥ + ⎡ ⎣⎢ ⎤ ⎦⎥max . max .

The maximum calibration error of the thermocouple was 0.1 K. The maximum deviation related to the measuring of location of the thermocouples was about 0.1%. The measurement error of the power meter (multi-meter and current meter) was 0.5%. Maximum uncertainties of the heat flux and heat loss were also about 9% and less than 6%, respectively. The uncertainty of Heat Transfer Coefficient (HTC) according to Eq. (7) equals to 10.1%. Table 3 represents the uncertainty values of instruments used in the present work.

sections.heading: 3.1. Validation of experimental data
sections.text:
To check the integrity of results, experimental data for deionized water are compared to Cornwell–Houston correlation [38], Gorenflo and Rohsenow correlations [39] (for heat transfer coefficient
close to CHF) and Zuber [40] (for CHF) at different heat fluxes. Results of comparison have been presented in Fig. 6. As can be seen, results are in a good agreement with available correlations. The absolute average deviation values have been represented in Fig. 6. This
validation reveals that experimental data obtained for test CNT nanofluids would be highly reliable.
Noticeably, the Cornwell–Houston correlation can predict the pool boiling heat transfer coefficient of deionized water with higher accuracy than other correlations. As can be seen for other correlations, experimental results have been under-predicted and over-predicted by Rohsenow and Gorenflo correlations, respectively. Because Rohsenow and Gorenflo correlations depend on the thermo-fluid properties and their internal tuning parameters, which should accurately be adjusted. Since properties of DIW are well known and available in handbooks, therefore, these correlations can be considered as the reference. Likewise, Zuber correlation predicts the CHF point with a reasonable accuracy in comparison with our work (1100 vs. 1170 kW/m2).
Fig. 7 illustrates the influence of applied heat flux on the bubble formation phenomena. Expectedly, the rate of bubble generation is significantly intensified, when heat flux increases. At heat fluxes near the boiling crisis point, bubbles cover the heating surface, and a vapor blanket is formed on the surface with a mushroom shape, which can partially isolate the surface. Therefore, heat transfer coefficient is deteriorated at critical heat flux point. This phenomenon usually leads the hot spots and dry-out to be formed on the heater. If heater cannot tolerate such heat loads, serious damages occur on the heater, which finally leads to the heater failure. Later, we will discuss on the potential role of deposition on capillary action and re-wetting capability of boiling surface.
After validating the results, experiments on the thermal performance of non-FCNT and FCNT nano-fluids are conducted and discussed in following sections.

sections.heading: 3.2. Fouling formation and heat transfer coefficient of FCNT
sections.text:
Fig. 8 demonstrates the experimentally quantified pool boiling heat transfer coefficient of FCNT nano-fluids at different mass concentrations. As expected, by increasing the applied heat flux to the boiling surface, the heat transfer coefficient considerably increases. In fact, intensification of heat flux enhances the rate of bubble formation and rate of heat transfer on the surface as well, which leads the local agitation, bubble interaction and micro/ macro convection streams around the bubbles to be intensified too. Likewise, by increasing the mass concentration of carbon nanotubes, pool boiling heat transfer coefficient increases, while the rate of increase of heat transfer coefficient in low heat flux region is lower than that of reported in moderate and high heat flux regions. As can be seen, the heat transfer coefficient for CNT nano-fluids are higher than deionized water. The reason for this fact can be referred to the internal thermal conductivity of carbon nanotubes, Brownian motion of FCNTs inside the bulk of nano-fluids, and thermal diffusion from the surface to the bulk of nano-fluids (thermophoresis phenomenon) [8].
Interestingly, functionalized nano-fluid seems to have the weak tendency to create fouling on the surface, since the carboxyl group attached on the carbon nanotube hinders the particulate fouling formation of nano-fluid on the surface. Therefore, micro-cavities, irregularities and roughness of surface can remain untouched or slightly changes with fouling formation. For better understanding of fouling on the boiling surface, fouling resistance thermal term is defined as:
R h t h t f = ( ) − =( ) 1 1 0 (8)
In Eq. (8), Rf is thermal fouling resistance and h t( ) is the timedependent pool boiling heat transfer coefficient, h(t = 0) is the initial heat transfer coefficient of surface when no particulate fouling is observed on the heater (clean surface). In order to measure the fouling resistance, transient experiments should be carried out over the extended time of 1000 min.Fig. 9 shows the fouling resistance versus time for FCNT at heat flux 450 kW/m2. As can be seen, fouling resistance for functionalized nano-fluid is a rectilinear function of time with a very slight slope of increase, meaning that by increasing the time, fouling resistance value increases slightly. Besides, mass concentration of nano-fluid intensifies the fouling resistance of FCNT nano-fluids. The higher mass concentration, the higher fouling resistance is obtained. Slope of increase is a direct function of mass concentration too. By increasing the wt.% of nano-fluids, rate of increase of fouling resistance significantly enhances.
Noticeably, for other heat fluxes, similar rectilinear behavior of fouling for FCNT nano-fluids was seen such that with increasing the heat flux and mass concentration, the value of fouling resistance parameter increases.

sections.heading: 3.3. Fouling and heat transfer coefficient of CNT
sections.text:
In this stage, experiments were performed with CNTs without functionalizing process. Experimental results showed that the heat transfer coefficient decreases for the CNT/water nano-fluids when comparing to the FCNT. The reason for this phenomenon is the stability behavior of nano-fluids during the experiments. FCNT nanofluids have longer stability and lower tendency to deposit on the surface, while CNT nano-fluids create a deposition layer, which reduces the roughness of surface. Therefore, number of potential
nucleation sites over the extended time reduces and subsequently, bubble transport becomes weaker. Fig. 10 presents the heat transfer coefficient of CNT aqueous nano-fluids versus the applied heat flux. As can be seen, by increasing the mass concentration of nanofluids, rate of deterioration is intensified. However, for all mass concentrations, heat transfer coefficient is lower than deionized water. Moreover, the critical heat flux value for CNT is still lower than that of obtained for FCNT, which is mainly due to the irregular fouling formation of nanotubes on the surface. It can generally be stated that, for FCNT nano-fluid, a fouling layer is constituted on the surface, which absorbs the liquid from the bulk of nanofluid due to its capillary action. Noticeably, the fouling layer for FCNT is uniform and porous; therefore, capillary action can be intensified in porous medium. However, for CNT nano-fluids, rate of fouling is extensive and irregular deposition is formed, which have no impact on the capillary action of surface. More importantly, such depositions can fill or cover the micro/nano cavities on the surface and subsequently, suppress the bubble transport mechanism due to the reduction in roughness of surface and effective heat transfer surface area. Likewise, higher values for fouling thermal resistance parameter are registered for CNT nano-fluids. On the other hand, it is expected that boiling surface characteristics be affected by the deposition layer such as surface wettability [41,42], which is discussed in section 3.4.
Briefly speaking, the pool boiling heat transfer coefficient for CNT nano-fluids at different mass concentrations are close to each other such that they overlapped each other at high heat flux region. This means that none-functionalized CNTs are not suitable for convective/ boiling systems, however, slight enhancement for CHF can be seen in comparison with that of measured for base fluid.
Fig. 11 shows the thermal resistance for CNT nano-fluids at heat flux of 450 kW/m2. As can be seen, the order of magnitude for thermal fouling resistance of CNT is 10-fold larger than FCNT nanofluids. In addition, asymptotic behavior is obtained for CNT fouling resistance parameter, which is in accordance with our previous results [8,43–48]. Noticeably, there are some fluctuations in results, which are due to the repellant role of bubbles, which destruct the equilibrium state of temperature on the surface and induce fluctuation in thermocouple readings. Better to say that CNTs are not strongly attached to the surface and can be easily detached from the surface by collapsing or departing the bubbles. Therefore, nanotubes can depart the surface and subsequently, temperature
profile is consequently changed and as the results, some fluctuations can be seen during the experiments.

sections.heading: 3.4. Contact angle
sections.text:
Changing the surface wettability is one of the major impacts of deposition layer of CNTs and FCNTs. In this work, contact angle of water droplet on the discoid heater before and after the boiling experiments have been measured using digital microscopic photography. Taken images can provide a precise of 5 μm per pixel, so visually determining the contact angle is reliable. For such photographic facility, a ballast lamp was implemented, which can reduce the light flicker problem considerably better than conventional lights. Fig. 12 shows the measured contact angle of surface before and after boiling experiments. Note that the approximate volume of each drop is identical and less than 1 μL. The time of photography is 750 milliseconds for each shot.
As can be seen in Fig. 12, FCNT nano-fluids provide the lower contact angle (higher wettability) in comparison with CNT nanofluid (lower wettability). These findings are consistent with previous researches regarding the contact angles of nano-fluid in boiling phenomena [41,42,49–51]. Therefore, in case of using FCNT nanofluids, liquid droplets can lie on the surface. In addition, more liquid can be absorbed by deposition layer. Consequently, due to the
capillary action inside the deposition layer, liquid is transferred to the dry-out regions, and CHF can be enhanced.

sections.heading: 3.5. Mean surface roughness
sections.text:
During the boiling experiments, surface roughness is constantly changed over the extend time. This parameter can be regarded as a criterion for characterizing the boiling surface. In order to measure the roughness of surface, Elcometer surface roughness tester was employed. Surface was also polished using emery paper grit 220–240. For each experiment, surface of heater was analyzed to investigate the influence of CNTs or FCNTs on the surface. Results of this work demonstrated that CNT nano-fluids could considerably decrease the roughness of surface. This decreasing trend can be intensified if mass concentration of nano-fluid increases. In case of increasing the mass concentration of nano-fluid, more nanotubes have the opportunity to be attached to the boiling surface and subsequently can partially/fully cover the microstructures. Therefore, effective heat transfer area and potential nucleation sites may be diminished over the time. However, for FCNT, rate of deposition is significantly lower than CNT, because FCNT does not have the tendency for forming the aggregations and clusters due to the carboxyl group attached on the main body of the nanotube. As a result, roughness of surface slightly changes over the extended time. More importantly, a small layer of deposition on the boiling surface can be seen for FCNT, but is insignificant in comparison with CNT. In previous works, for nanoparticles (not nanotubes) ratio of mean size of nanotubes to the average roughness of heater has been marked as a determinative parameter for decreasing or increasing the roughness of boiling surface. If this ratio is much lower than unity, then roughness of surface will be decreased during the boiling heat transfer [52]. However for carbon nanotube, not only the mean diameter, but also the type of CNT, size of cross-links, length of tubes and type of functional group (for functionalized nanotubes) may have potential impacts on surface roughness and thermal performance of system, which are recommended to be carefully studied but is out of goals of this work. Noticeably, CNTs may constitute layers of nonporous fouling, which cannot provide the enough wicking capillary action in comparison with FCNT. Therefore, rate of CHF enhancement for FCNT is relatively higher than CNT nano-fluids. Results have been proved by other previous works such as [53]. Fig. 13 represents the results of roughness tests for discoid heater surface before and after boiling of FCNT and CNT nano-fluids.
Before drawing a conclusion, results have been presented in Table 4, which comparatively presents the rough comparison between two types of nano-fluids. As can be seen, FCNT nanofluids can widely be used for boiling/convective systems and CHF enhancement due to its lower fouling formation and its regular
Fig. 11. Comparison between thermal fouling resistances of non-FCNT/water nanofluids. Influence of mass concentration of nano-fluid.
porous deposition on the surface. For CNTs, formation of relatively irregular layer of fouling weakens the capillary wicking action on the heater. The fouling layer decreases the heat transfer coefficient due to the fouling thermal resistance and slightly enhances the CHF.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
Experimental investigations on pool boiling heat transfer to functionalized and non-functionalized carbon nanotube nanofluids have been performed on a discoid heater under the atmospheric pressure. Results demonstrated that FCNT nano-fluid is a promising option for nucleate boiling heat transfer, since it can enhance the heat transfer coefficient and critical heat flux point, however for CNT, a slight enhancement in CHF was reported.
Likewise, their fouling behavior was very different (rectilinear for FCNT and asymptotic for CNT). In addition, fouling of nonfunctionalized nano-fluid was extensively higher than that of registered for functionalized nano-fluid. More importantly, contact angle as the main surface characteristic was found to be strongly under influence by the type of CNT nano-fluid such that for FCNT, contact angle significantly decreased and surface characteristics changed toward the hydrophilic surface. While for CNT, rate of decrease in contact angle was not so significant that remained the surface hydrophobic. Therefore, for the hydrophilic surface, higher rate of enhancement in CHF was registered, which is due to the surface capillary wicking action.
Nomenclatures
All symbols, parameters and formulas have been explained through the manuscript.

sections.text: Authors of this work tend to dedicate this article to Imam Mahdi and appreciate Semnan University for their facilities.

referenceMentions.context: Nano-fluids (a traditional coolant such as water comprising the solid particles with size of 0–100 nm, which was called “Nano-fluids” by Choi [1]) are promising nominations for future of advanced thermal fluids due to their outstanding thermal conductivity.
For example, Ahn and his co-workers [19] established experiments on forced convection and CHF characteristics of nano-fluids.
[20] conducted an experimental study on flow boiling CHF of alumina nano-fluid and alumina coated tubes.
An experimental study was carried out by Yang and Liu [21] to investigate the pool boiling heat transfer characteristics of functionalized nano-fluid at atmospheric and subatmospheric pressures.
[22] experimentally investigated on boiling characteristic of SiC nano-fluid and evaluated the thermal performance of SiC nanoparticles in water pool boiling up to CHF.
[32] has conducted experiments on pool boiling heat transfer of MWCNT/water nano-fluids.
[33] performed investigations regarding boiling heat transfer of multi-walled carbon nanotube suspension in pure water and water containing 9.

[34] showed that enhancement in boiling heat transfer can be intensified using CNT coatings on the heating surface.
[35] studied the pool boiling heat transfer of CNT nanofluids under subatmospheric pressure and concluded that pressure has great impacts on heat transfer coefficient.

[36] established several experiments to quantify the nucleate pool boiling heat transfer coefficient and characteristics of aqueous CNT nanofluids up to critical heat flux on a square flat copper heater.
To check the uncertainty of experiments, Kline-McKlintock method [37] was used.

close to CHF) and Zuber [40] (for CHF) at different heat fluxes.

The reason for this fact can be referred to the internal thermal conductivity of carbon nanotubes, Brownian motion of FCNTs inside the bulk of nano-fluids, and thermal diffusion from the surface to the bulk of nano-fluids (thermophoresis phenomenon) [8].

metadata.abstractText: Pool boiling heat transfer coefficient (HTC) of functionalized carbon nanotube (FCNT) and nonfunctionalized carbon nanotube (CNT) is experimentally quantified at high-heat flux conditions up to the critical heat flux (CHF) point. Nano-fluids are prepared using two-step method and are well dispersed within the deionized water, followed by functionalizing (by carboxyl group), sonication and adding the nonylphenolethoxylates nonionic surfactant as a dispersant. In terms of stability, results showed that FCNT could be stable up to three successive weeks, while seven days of stability was registered for nonFCNT. In addition, FCNT considerably enhance the heat transfer coefficient and CHF point. Since this nanofluid does not change the roughness of surface considerably and has great wettability in comparison with CNT nano-fluid. Results also demonstrated although fouling formation of functionalized carbon nanotube is insignificant in comparison with CNT, the lower contact angle between liquid droplet and the surface caused more liquid to be absorbed by the porous fouling layer. Therefore, more liquid are available on the surface, which leads the dry-out regions to be re-wetted. Consequently, significant enhancement in CHF point was registered for FCNT nano-fluids in comparison with CNT. In terms of fouling behavior, asymptotic behavior for fouling resistance is seen for CNT, while the rectilinear fouling behavior was seen
